Now, the problem is asking for the probability of drawing four cards of the same rank. That means I need to pick all four cards that share the same rank, like all four aces, or all four kings, or all four queens, and so on.

I think the first step is to figure out the total number of possible ways to draw four cards from the deck, regardless of their ranks. Since the order doesn't matter here, I believe this is a combination problem. The formula for combinations is C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n - k)!), where n is the total number of items, and k is the number of items to choose.

So, in this case, n = 52 (total cards), and k = 4 (cards to draw). Plugging into the formula:

Total possible combinations = C(52, 4) = 52! / (4!(52 - 4)!) = (52 × 51 × 50 × 49) / (4 × 3 × 2 × 1) = 270,725.

Alright, so there are 270,725 different ways to draw four cards from the deck.

Next, I need to find out how many of these combinations consist of all four cards being of the same rank. Since there are 13 ranks in the deck (ace through king), and for each rank, there's only one way to choose all four cards of that rank (because there are exactly four cards per rank).
